risinfo.chaptertitle: 3. Presenting Problem, History of Presenting Problem, and Social History

sect1.title: Summary and Conclusions
sect1.para: Before concluding the interview, the clinician may want to follow up on any missing information to clarify or narrow down diagnostic hypotheses (e. g., has the client endorsed all necessary symptoms to meet the criteria for a hypothesized disorder) and inquire about any information gaps. Clients may be hesitant to disclose information early in the interview process but may feel more comfortable after some rapport has been developed. Providing space for the client to share any additional information may allow them to provide information they left out earlier in the process (e. g., “Have we covered everything you wanted me to know today,” “Is there anything else you would like to tell me?”). The clinician may also use the closing stage of the interview for one final exploration of the client’s secret questions (e. g., “After our discussion today, what are your thoughts about your symptoms and presenting problems?”). Before closing the interview, the clinician should take a few minutes to summarize the process and prepare the client for feedback. This is done by naming the presenting problem and the client’s reasons for seeking assessment, summarizing notable themes and issues, providing an early case formulation as appropriate, and scheduling future sessions.
